events.target_title: Cannot scroll in gtk3/4 apps after interacting with plasmashell

note.body:
@jat255 Setting `GDK_CORE_DEVICE_EVENTS=1` completely disables touchpad smooth scrolling and touchscreen support, along with all other benefits that come with XInput2.

I am currently using KDE Plasma as my DE and kwin as my WM. For me, this problem manifests in applications using GTK3 or 4 as being unable to scroll inactive windows and sometimes completely losing the ability to scroll at all. Using the touchpad or touchscreen works, however. Applications using qt or gtk2 scroll fine. Chrome also seems to work completely fine. In Firefox, this problem only exists when the `MOZ_USE_XINPUT2` environment variable is set to 1. Without that environment variable, behavior of firefox is identical to that of other gtk applications with `GDK_CORE_DEVICE_EVENTS` set.

I do not consider setting `GDK_CORE_DEVICE_EVENTS` as a valid workaround as it disables using the touchscreen for scrolling, which in turn makes using only the touchscreen very difficult.

<https://bugs.kde.org/show_bug.cgi?id=348270#c26> seems to provide an explanation for why this happens. From there, it can also be seen that this problem is about 4 years old. According to that thread, the patch submitted with #558 would have fixed the problem, but was reverted. <https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=750870> is another issue closely related to this one.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
It is sad to see this. It is the same reason that I refuse to use GTK3.

The problem is that most TrueType fonts are rendered poorly unless you have a high-DPI/"retina" display, which most people do not have.  
Also, remember that embedded devices usually have low-resolution screens (like 128\*128 or 64\*64).  
If you enable antialiasing you get blurry texts. If you disable antialiasing you get out-of-shape texts.  
Bitmap fonts have no such problems because they are pixel-perfect and does not require antialiasing if a fixed font size is specified (which in most cases is).  
Last but not least, bitmap fonts are easy to edit, unlike TrueType fonts.  
Also, not everyone uses a DE like GNOME. I (and many people) use WMs like i3 and TWM because they use fewer resources and has fewer distractions.  
If I use a minimal WM and I use the terminal all day long, obviously I want the UI font to be the same as the terminal font.

events.target_title: Pango 1.44 and the removal of support for bitmap fonts

note.body:
@nwaxweiler I have read the comments.  
The problem is that on some configurations, TTF/OTF is treated differently.  
For example, if a bitmap is 7 px in height, it will be displayed without scaling (if I set the text height to 14 px it would simply double the pixels and you still get sharp text); but with TTF/OTF, it will scale the font based on its shape, resulting in blurry or broken edges. The same thing would happen if there is a 1 px or 2 px difference between the font and the text height: with bitmap fonts it adds empty lines below the text, and with TTF/OTF it will scale. Maybe that is a problem with fontconfig but bitmap fonts worked before.  
Last but not least, bitmap fonts is faster to render.

events.target_title: Custom gnome shell theme ( only recolor the bluish) not work as expected

note.body:
To elaborate: the issue is with gdm theming. The same theme (https://github.com/Chrysostomus/adwaita-maia/tree/master/theme/adwaita-maia-dark/gnome-shell) works without issue when applied as shell theme. However, when it is compiled into gresource file to use with gdm, and default is selected for gnome-shell theme, the issue of invisible search results in shell emerges.

So, the issue doesn't occur if we use a gnome-shell theme that matches gdm theme OR if we use gnome-shell that is patched to use the custom color. 

So, we figured we are doing something wrong in how we are applying the gdm theme. We would be grateful for any pointers on how to properly package the gdm theme.

events.target_title: Custom gnome shell theme ( only recolor the bluish) not work as expected

note.body:
Thank you very much for your help! The issue seems indeed similar to the yaru issue. 

We were able somehow resolve the issue for now by adjusting the xml used to generate gresource file so that it did not include icons/ directory. Or, it might have been some of the other changes, the whole build script was rewritten a few times. We'll check _common_scss to ensure that the issue won't repeat.

Again, thank you for your help and time! We really appreciate it.

events.target_title: new event time bug
Mail signature is changed when reopening an email in the Drafts/Outbox

note.body:
Steps to reproduce:

* Evolution-3.32.4-1.mga8 (x86_64)
* Have two IMAP accounts defined, with "On this computer" as default
* First IMAP account listed has a signature defined to be attached to new emails
* The second listed IMAP account has a signature defined but the default it not to automatically add the signature to any e-mail
* Create a message (new, response or forward) "from" the second listed IMAP account (in online or offline mode)
* See that no signature is added and hit send
* Go to Outbox folder under "On This Computer"
* Open the just-composed e-mail

Expected outcome:

The message will have no signature

Actual outcome:

The signature of the first account listed is added, even though the message still correctly shows as coming from the "second" account

(Thanks to the original poster for a wonderful bug-reporting "template")

note.body:
This is the code I modified.
```shell
  tests: $(PYTESTS)
        @for f in $(XMLS) ; do test -f $$f || $(LN_S) $(srcdir)/$$f . ; done
        @echo "## running Python regression tests"
-       -@(PYTHONPATH="..:../.libs:$(srcdir)/..:$$PYTHONPATH" ; \
+       @(PYTHONPATH="..:../.libs:$(srcdir)/..:$$PYTHONPATH" ; \
           export PYTHONPATH; \
           LD_LIBRARY_PATH="$(top_builddir)/.libs:$$LD_LIBRARY_PATH" ; \
           export LD_LIBRARY_PATH; \
           for test in $(PYTESTS) ; \
           do log=`$(PYTHON) $(srcdir)/$$test` ; \
           if [ "`echo $$log | grep OK`" = "" ] ; then \
-          echo "-- $$test" ; echo "$$log" ; fi ; done)
+          echo "-- $$test" ; echo "$$log" ; exit 1 ; fi ; done)
```

events.target_title: Support for single-/multi- page DjVu documents

note.body:
This is another example of such file: 

* [Markus_Heitkoetter-How_To_Make_Money_With_Trading_Systems-Rockwell_Trading.djvu](/uploads/52d19f3c8611075d214456495ba4433d/Markus_Heitkoetter-How_To_Make_Money_With_Trading_Systems-Rockwell_Trading.djvu)

`xdg-mime query filetype` prints `image/vnd.djvu+multipage`, but `file --mime-type` returns `image/vnd.djvu` only.

Firefox 60 didn't offer to "Open With" Evince and (!) neither did it's `GtkAppChooserWidget`. That's simply because evince's desktop entry doesn't contain `image/vnd.djvu`.

There is popular demand:
* https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evince/issues/949
* https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=786511
* https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=754467#c8
* https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=876710
* https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/djvulibre/+bug/1778088

If Evince supports a certain type, it makes no sense not to merely list it — the default application to actually use (such as an image viewer) is a matter of _xdg-mime defaults_.

@hadess, wouldn't you consider reverting https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/evince/commit/39bd98c5fb954e3b6723370b2f6b60ea43091db3 ?

events.target_title: Key repeat settings are hard to find, confusing, and hard to test

note.body:
I was about to create a bug for this, saying:
>  I find it very counter-intuitive that the keyboard repeat rate/delay settings are not under keyboard settings.  Even searching for them is hit-and-miss, for example "keyboard repeat" finds nothing, and even "repeat keys" (the name of the setting) finds nothing.  Only when you search for "repeat" does it identify the "Universal Access" control panel as the place to go.  And when you eventually do get there, the settings remain invisible until you click on the Repeat: on/off button... which has a hidden dialogue behind it, and nothing in the user interface to indicate that something is hidden there.

Then I found this bug that echoes my sentiments almost exactly.  I'm not sure why it's taking so long to implement, it seems like an obvious requirement to me?

In that (possibly very outdated?) design mock-up, "Bounce Keys" would better be described "Ignores fast duplicate keypresses".  Probably already fixed...

I have no music on the machine it's installed on, I only use lollypop as a very pretty web player (spotify and such). I went into preferences and pointed it to an empty scratch folder and the memory insanity is solved.

Not sure what the best way to alleviate this issue would be for new users, but it definitely was not a pleasant suprise haha! Maybe on first launch, ask to point to where your media is instead of just scanning the entire home partition?

The only clear pattern is these are meetings where the organizer is in a different timezone such as Americas/New_York and Atlantic/Reykjavik, I'm in Americas/Los_Angeles.

I'm asking on the Arch forum if others see the issue

events.target_title: breaks password-based SSH when there are too many SSH keys

note.body:
> In most cases it works...

I'm hitting this problem now that I've got six ssh keys loaded into gnome-keyring-daemon; when I try to access a host that needs the sixth ssh key, I get rejected because that host's sshd only allows 5 authentication attempts per connection (see MaxAuthTries in /etc/ssh/sshd_config).  To compound the problem, it adds a firewall rule to block access after 3 connection failures, but that's unrelated to gnome-keyring.

Before gnome-keyring, I could have typed 'ssh-add -d some-key' or 'ssh-add -D' and been able to log in again, but gnome-keyring is treating these keys as undeletable.

It's confusing when gnome-keyring locks automatically-loaded keys upon typing 'ssh-add -D': 'ssh-add -l' doesn't show if keys are locked or not.  Does 'ssh-add -X' unlock them?

As a workaround, explicitly specifying which key to use on the command line or in ~/.ssh/config solves the problem.

Request:
* Please make 'ssh-add' able to delete all keys from gnome-keyring-daemon like it does with ssh-agent.
* Possible enhancement: refuse to add any more keys if five (configurable) are already loaded?

Thanks!

Reference: https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=472477

events.target_title: X11 Error rendering pixbuf cache with large pixbufs.

note.body:
I would like to point out that my hunch about the large pixbuf size was indeed true. height=height@entry=34768.  That pixbuf is too large for broken intel video drivers :)

```
#9  0x00007ffff6315723 in _cairo_xlib_shm_surface_create (format=PIXMAN_x8r8g8b8, width=width@entry=1167, height=height@entry=34768, will_sync=will_sync@entry=0, create_pixmap=4096, 
    other=<optimized out>, other=<optimized out>) at /usr/src/debug/x11-libs/cairo-1.16.0-r3/cairo-1.16.0/src/cairo-xlib-surface-shm.c:843
```

note.body: I can make this happen pretty reliably just let me know if more traces or information is needed.

events.target_title: Update the XCF docs to any 2.10 changes

note.body:
The question here is: Is XCF 2.10 format open sourced? If it is, it's clear any application could read it without issues.

Thank you

events.target_title: Update the XCF docs to any 2.10 changes

note.body:
But it's an `unofficial condensation` ... where is the official and not condensed?

thank you again

events.target_title: Update the XCF docs to any 2.10 changes

note.body:
Someone? Someone of the project, that documented the source code, who knows how and why each code line is there, is the adequate person to write the official documentation of XCF 2.10 format. Is like if a chef creates a cooking recipe but didn't write anything about the quantity of each ingredient, the time to cooking each one, ... Documentation must be precise. As a consequence, near two years after GIMP 2.10 was launched, nowadays there are no any free (or not) software able to read XCF 2.10 format. 

Something does not work in the development of GIMP

events.target_title: Update the XCF docs to any 2.10 changes

note.body:
Seriously? So, are your telling that users that BET for GNU/GPL software should ask for why developers of GIMP are not interested in update their docs? (as we are asking in this thread). It's a pity. That's not the way, clearly. Other projects do their homework on time and usual users have a better feedback with their developers. Obviously,  casual users doesn't care if a project team provides all docs that let other developers to carry out a serious workflow to usual users.

Maybe I'm wrong, but time will show who is right.

events.target_title: Update the XCF docs to any 2.10 changes

note.body:
On first place, thank you, @Jehan , for try to bring some light to this thread. When I wrote `unofficial condensation` I only pasted exactly what was wrote in "Status" paragraph of document https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/3990#note_611547 (reported in https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gimp/issues/3990#note_611547). Maybe he linked to an outdated document or maybe I don't understand correctly "unofficial condensation".

The fact is that, as @maderios wrote, there is no current image viewer/manager able to show XCF thumbnails. I know that someone tried as the great XNview (https://newsgroup.xnview.com/viewtopic.php?t=37464) but still is not working. I don't use Gnome, but I'm afraid even that desktop environment doesn't take too much attention to the new format as they SHOULD cause GIMP is a great application, but needs an ecosystem that support it making a photographer/designer to have a natural workflow where GIMP should be one of the gears to impulse people to take seriously Free Software. And today, that's not the situation. I introduced some professional photographers on free software workflow for his job. Fighting with colord, Argyll, darktable - digikam - gimp/krita,  Linux compatible hardware ... a single change in their workflow, as not being able to see their jobs as they was working, it's a great stone in the path. One of them finally told me he can't continue working that way and abandoned free software. This is not about GIMP, don't take my words wrong, is about Linux desktop environment, that is far from being for professionals that simply need to do his job. I could talk about the impossible sound equalization with PulseAudio and continue with the poor integration of gnome/plasma when working with remote documents in a LAN ... but I'm somehow frustrated after 10 years using Linux as desktop PC and see that Window$ continue doing it better.

I'm sorry for my small talk, but this is what I'm feeling.

Best regards , sincerely

events.target_title: Huge memory consumption for 13 pages PDF with annotations

note.body:
This bug is alive and well in Evince 3.32.0 (Fedora 30). I've observed this behavior for a couple of years, at least. But recently it appears to have got worse.

Each annotation adds a considerable amount of resident RAM. For the document attached by the reporter, when I open it the resident size of Evince is 325 MB. As I scroll down to the end of the document it balloons to 2.4 GB.

Moreover, If I open a copy and scroll down in the new window, it keeps increasing and reaches 4.6 GB resident. If I close this new copy, the resident size stays the same, indicating some sort of memory leak.

Germán mentioned profiling. I can try to do it, if someone gives me some starting pointers.

note.body:
Interestingly, I discovered gnome-music on my laptop with Fedora 31 Beta plays songs as expected.  The issue was only on my desktop PC with Fedora 31 Beta installed.  I ran "rpm -qa | grep -i gstreamer1" on each computer and found some gstreamer package differences between them.  I removed and installed gstreamer1 packages on my desktop to match the laptop and now gnome-music works on both computers.

Package changes made were:
rpm -e gstreamer1-plugins-ugly-1.16.0-3.fc31.x86_64
dnf install gstreamer1-plugin-openh264
dnf install gstreamer1-plugins-bad-free
dnf install gstreamer1-plugins-bad-freeworld
dnf install libnice-gstreamer1

Installed gstreamer1 packages on both PCs are:
gstreamer1-1.16.1-1.fc31.x86_64
gstreamer1-libav-1.16.0-2.fc31.x86_64
gstreamer1-plugin-openh264-1.16.0-1.fc31.x86_64

Sure, i already look at this with PM to see if it doesn't have access to certain dlls, but from what i can tell, every plugin is searching for the DLL files in 3 directories:
1. The BIN folder
2. The plugin directory (each plugin searches in its directory)
3. System64 (C:\Windows\System32) - For 64bit plugins
4. System32 (C:\Windows\Syswow64) - For 32bit plugins

And, as far as i can tell, it searches in the redirected System32/System64, and the real System32 and Syswow64 present on the machine.

note.body:
May I kindly ask for more detailed clarifications as to why closing this issue? What does MR mean?

This is indeed not currently supported, which is the whole point of the issue: to make sure that it will be supported in the near future. Are you actually saying that you do not want to support this as a design choice? Such position would seem quite surprising. As is, not being able to call Gimp via a symlink basically means that the whole Gimp batch mode is impractical to use on macOS, and in particular not working at all when installing Gimp using Homebrew, which is throwing away thousands of perfectly working lines of code of functionality. The fix to support this is less than half a dozen lines of code and already provided in this thread.

I'm happy to help implementing it, I'd just need guidance as I have never compiled GIMP from source or contributed to the project.

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10.10 build for OSX unable to be started using a symlink

note.body:
Thanks for the reply. Hopefully, the new wrapper would allow this. Still, my opinion is that it would be better practice to leave this open. It seems unusual to close active and reproducible bug reports based on current time constraints to implement the fix. Somebody else might indeed implement it, as you suggested.

Indeed, there are workarounds, but they are quite inconvenient, which is why I said "impractical", although I suppose this was a bit too strong a word. The most obvious problem is that when users face the problem, they must Google it and find the cause, which is far from obvious from the error message. Hopefully, they discover this thread, and somehow implement a workaround which may not be trivial for them, depending on their knowledge. I'd say that the whole process could take anywhere from 30min to several days.

In my case, I was using a script to generate icons, which expects GIMP to be available as `gimp`. See: https://github.com/vgc/vgc-icons/blob/master/iconify.sh. This worked fine on Linux, but I needed to port it to macOS to also generate *.icns files using Apple built-in tools. Ideally, this should be doable in automated builds such as in TravisCI, in which case installing GIMP using HomebrewCask is typically the most obvious/supported choice. My first frustration was that HomebrewCask didn't install a symlink to have GIMP available as `gimp` (as is done for `inkscape`, for example). So I had to report this, and managed to get it merged upstream: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-cask/issues/69939

Unfortunately, this still didn't work, as it turns out that GIMP fails when called from a symlink. In my case, as I am the author of the script, I could modify it to determine the actual location of GIMP, and use this, see: https://github.com/vgc/vgc-icons/blob/master/iconify.sh#L84.

But others may indeed not have the choice to modify an external script. Instead, they should write their own wrapper, add it to their PATH, make sure it has higher priority, and worst of all in a maintenance perspective: they should adapt the wrapper when GIMP changes. It really isn't a real solution.

I hope it was useful to provide more context.

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10.10 build for OSX unable to be started using a symlink

note.body:
To be honest I'm not so familiar with this stuff and even less on macOS. For one thing, my understanding is that `realpath` is not provided by default in macOS and therefore should be avoided. There is `readlink`, but I believe it fails if the given path is not a symlink:

https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/System/Conceptual/ManPages_iPhoneOS/man2/readlink.2.html

There might be useful info on how to go about this here:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1055671/how-can-i-get-the-behavior-of-gnus-readlink-f-on-a-mac

events.target_title: Gimp 2.10.10 build for OSX unable to be started using a symlink

note.body:
Alright, in the official release of GIMP 2.10.12, in the file `GIMP-2.10.app/Contents/MacOS/gimp`, replacing:

```
BASEDIR=$(cd `dirname $0` && pwd)
```

by

```
# Locate this file, iterating down a (possible) chain of symlinks
THIS_FILE=$0
while [ -L "$THIS_FILE" ]
do
    THIS_FILE=`readlink $THIS_FILE`
done

BASEDIR=$(cd `dirname $THIS_FILE` && pwd)
```

seems to work well, at least my macOS 10.14.

If we do this, we're calling `./gimp_bin` from the actual directory where `gimp_bin` lives. Even if the wrapper was called from a softlink, `./gimp_bin` is never aware of this.

events.target_title: Add pidfd support to GLib

note.body:
Heyho,

pidfd maintainer here. :) The timeline is:

##### 5.1:
- `pidfd_send_signal()`

##### 5.2:
- `CLONE_PIDFD`
   
   The following call will place a pidfd in the `pidfd` return argument:

   ```c
   pid_t pid = clone(<fn>, <stack>, CLONE_PIDFD | SIGCHLD, NULL, &pidfd, NULL, NULL);
   ```

##### 5.3:
- `pidfd_open()`

   A pidfd for a process created without `CLONE_PIDFD` can be retrieved via

   ```c
   int pidfd = pidfd_open(<pid>, 0);
   ```

- `clone3()` syscall

   The following call will place a pidfd in the `pidfd` member of `struct clone_args`:

   ```c
   int pidfd = -EBADF;
   struct clone_args args {
           .pidfd = &pidfd,
           .exit_signal = SIGCHLD,
   };
   pid_t pid = clone3(&args, sizeof(args));
   ```

- polling support for pidfds created via `pidfd_open()` or `CLONE_PIDFD`

##### 5.4:
- `P_PIDFD` extension for `waitid()` syscall

   Processes can be waited upon via pidfd by using:

   ```c
   ret = waitid(P_PIDFD, pidfd, NULL, NULL, 0);
   ```

If you have needs/ideas for features feel free to reach out. :)

Christian

events.target_title: Save As dropdown menu gets into the way, should be optional

note.body:
This is the problem. to replicate, save as, and then type anything new for filename, then change directory using the breadcrumbs:
![Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-05-19](/uploads/4fae3e66b93fe3beb629cb6ca84bb73b/Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-05-19.png)
If you select something, it erases what you wrote for a filename and replaces it with the selected folder.  Because of the design of file open dialog, you have to choose a name first before changing folders to avoid opening the (unwanted) search function, so selecting folder first is a worse pain because then you have to go and highlight your filename carefully to change it.  I can see how someone thought this would be useful, but it is not as implemented.

Anyway, choosing from the dropdown menu overwrites your filename and does this, which if executed changes the folder to the one in the filename input area:

![Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-08-02](/uploads/e9d6addbedbc38780d7b77649cccbfdc/Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-08-02.png)

Unless, in chrome, for example, the filechooser appends a filetype that the filename input picks up. This time you will have a hidden file named .html and you better remember what folder you were in because the dialog closes after saving your new file, ".html"  Not sure why this happens for the html dialog in chrome but not for the pdf dialog in xreader, so besides being intrusive it is not consistent.

![Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-09-27](/uploads/6b7dda4d6153dcffde83efa826c84809/Screenshot_from_2019-10-02_00-09-27.png)

events.target_title: Suppress unnecessary translation related warnings on Windows
Suppress unnecessary translation related warnings on Windows

note.body:
I want to clarify this issue a bit. You can see the following message when launching meld on Windows:

```
$ meld
Couldn't bind the translation domain. Some translations won't work.
[WinError 126] The specified module could not be found
```

In this case, if you apply the following changes, no warning messages are displayed and it seems that it works correctly. 

```
--- ./meld.org   2019-10-04 16:15:48.169707300 +0900
+++ ./meld.mod   2019-10-04 16:13:48.529466300 +0900
@@ -112,15 +112,9 @@ except AttributeError:

 try:
     if os.name == 'nt':
-        from ctypes import cdll
-        if frozen:
-            libintl = cdll['libintl-8']
-        else:
-            libintl = cdll.intl
-        libintl.bindtextdomain(locale_domain, locale_dir)
-        libintl.bind_textdomain_codeset(locale_domain, 'UTF-8')
-        libintl.textdomain(locale_domain)
-        del libintl
+        import gettext
+        gettext.bindtextdomain(locale_domain, locale_dir)
+        gettext.bind_textdomain_codeset(locale_domain, 'UTF-8')
     else:
         locale.bindtextdomain(locale_domain, locale_dir)
         locale.bind_textdomain_codeset(locale_domain, 'UTF-8')
```

However I don't know the way to guarantee if it's fully tested so I'd like you to double-check this change.

Timeout on start with Gnome-keyring 3.34.0 and Mate-Desktop on Archlinux

note.body: Mate session manager launches gnome-keyring-daemon before the main event loop runs, so it probably cannot send any reply. I guess the async variant with g_dbus_connection_flush() should fix this.

events.target_title: Timeout on start with Gnome-keyring 3.34.0 and Mate-Desktop on Archlinux

note.body: Reverting the change and changing call_sync to call + flush fixes the problem indeed.[revert-synchronuous.patch](/uploads/0727b3f0f0772e685a81d0ab55c96553/revert-synchronuous.patch)

events.target_title: Timeout on start with Gnome-keyring 3.34.0 and Mate-Desktop on Archlinux

note.body: I found that MATE does this just to look for GNOME_KEYRING_PID in stdout, which was removed in 2014 anyway. So the easiest fix is to remove this code in MATE and spawn gnome-keyring asynchronously.

note.body:
From a conversation I had with @jabiertxof earlier about KDE's Breeze icons:

@jabiertxof:
> Is possiblo add to icons 2 more that break new inklscape 1.0Beta? preferences-settings and inkscape-logo? Thanks in advance

@noahadvs:
> Yes, we can add more icons. However, adding those icons did not completely fix the problems in Inkscape's UI.
> 
> It seems like the root of the problem is that Inkscape doesn't force icons to shrink to to the sizes set in Inkscape's Interface preferences (Larger, Large, Small, Smaller). Instead, Inkscape expands the UI elements to fit the icons at their smallest available size.
>
> [Screenshot_20191002_184050](/uploads/047309ac35a46887a0e932034c28274a/Screenshot_20191002_184050.png)
> The icon size is set to Large, but there is a mix of 32x32, 22x22 and 16x16 icons.
>
> Small and Smaller seem to be exactly the same, using only 16x16 icons
> [Screenshot_20191002_184503](/uploads/3f63b53bbf16ae1015140cc673bcfab8/Screenshot_20191002_184503.png) [Screenshot_20191002_184558](/uploads/0e525c6f0ce8db5e552a36800d29e785/Screenshot_20191002_184558.png)
